values.description:
If a plugin throws an exception, Gazebo can crash. This pull request remedies this situation by wrapping model plugin loading in try/catch blocks.

Separate pull requests will include code to handle other plugin types, and integration with gazebo2, 3, and 4.
values.title: Added exception handling to model plugins

values.description:
This pull request uses the `<axis><dynamics><friction>` tag to implements Coulomb joint friction (see Fig 1 in [this paper](http://robotics.tch.harvard.edu/publications/pdfs/armstrong1994survey.pdf), thanks to @traversaro for the suggestion). It is currently implemented for ODE revolute, prismatic, and slider joints using the [velocity and force parameters in the ODE joint motor](http://www.ode.org/ode-latest-userguide.html#sec_7_5_0) (see #381 for further discussion).

I've added a section to the `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` test to verify the `SetParam("friction", ...)` API, and I've also added a demo world: `worlds/joint_friction_demo.world` (note that it is generated from an embedded ruby template with suffic `.rworld`). In this world, there are several joints with different friction values that should behave differently. The universal joints are set to mimic the behavior of the revolute joints.

I should be able to get bullet to work in a similar manner. I will address this in a future pull request.

Caveats: the `ODEJoint::SetVelocity` had previously been using the ODE joint motors, so this function will currently interfere with joint friction. I plan to address this in a future pull request.

Apologies: I did some refactoring in the `ODEJoint::[GS]etParam` functions, which has made this diff a bit larger than it needed to be, but it allowed me to delete quite a bit of duplicate code.

Assorted comments:

* I also moved the sdf parameter loading from `ODEJoint::Load` to the parent class.
* I had to modify `Joint::Reset` to allow joint friction values to persist after a world reset (try resetting the demo world to verify that it works).
* I had to add a small fix to the `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` test to counteract the interference between SetVelocity and joint friction.

[Jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/214) is happy
values.title: Add joint friction for ODE revolute, prismatic, and universal joints (#381)

summary.html:
This pull request uses the <axis><dynamics><friction> tag to implements Coulomb joint friction (see Fig 1 in this paper, thanks to @traversaro for the suggestion). It is currently implemented for ODE revolute, prismatic, and slider joints using the velocity and force parameters in the ODE joint motor (see #381 for further discussion).

I've added a section to the INTEGRATION_joint_spawn test to verify the SetParam("friction", ...) API, and I've also added a demo world: worlds/joint_friction_demo.world (note that it is generated from an embedded ruby template with suffic .rworld). In this world, there are several joints with different friction values that should behave differently. The universal joints are set to mimic the behavior of the revolute joints.

I should be able to get bullet to work in a similar manner. I will address this in a future pull request.

Caveats: the ODEJoint::SetVelocity had previously been using the ODE joint motors, so this function will currently interfere with joint friction. I plan to address this in a future pull request.

Apologies: I did some refactoring in the ODEJoint::[GS]etParam functions, which has made this diff a bit larger than it needed to be, but it allowed me to delete quite a bit of duplicate code.

Assorted comments:

  • I also moved the sdf parameter loading from ODEJoint::Load to the parent class.
  • I had to modify Joint::Reset to allow joint friction values to persist after a world reset (try resetting the demo world to verify that it works).
  • I had to add a small fix to the INTEGRATION_joint_spawn test to counteract the interference between SetVelocity and joint friction.

Jenkins build is happy

values.description:
Based on the `arat.world` from pull request #1205, I've created a world plugin called ~~ARATPlugin~~ ArrangePlugin. Here's an example of the sdf parameters that it accepts:
~~~
<plugin name="arrange_plugin" filename="libArrangePlugin.so">
  <model_name>cricket_ball</model_name>
  <model_name>wood_block_10_2_1cm</model_name>
  <model_name>wood_cube_10cm</model_name>
  <model_name>wood_cube_7_5cm</model_name>
  <model_name>wood_cube_5cm</model_name>
  <model_name>wood_cube_2_5cm</model_name>
  <initial_arrangement>wood_blocks</initial_arrangement>
  <arrangement name="default">
    <pose model="cricket_ball"       > 0.6 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_block_10_2_1cm"> 0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_10cm"     > 0.2 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_7_5cm"    > 0.0 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_5cm"      >-0.2 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_2_5cm"    >-0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
  </arrangement>
  <arrangement name="cricket_ball">
    <pose model="cricket_ball"       > 0.6 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
  </arrangement>
  <arrangement name="wood_blocks">
    <pose model="wood_block_10_2_1cm"> 0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_10cm"     > 0.2 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_7_5cm"    > 0.0 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_5cm"      >-0.2 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_2_5cm"    >-0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
  </arrangement>
</plugin>
~~~

First, it accepts a sequence of `model_name` elements, with the names of models that should be arranged. The plugin stores the initial pose of these models internally.

It also accepts a sequence of `arrangement` elements that have a name attribute (for arrangement name) and child `pose` elements. The child pose elements have a model attribute that should match one of the `model_name` tags, and then pose data. Note that an arrangement doesn't require all poses to be listed (this will be explained below).

There is also an `initial_arrangement` element that should match one of the task names.

There is a `ArrangePlugin::SetArrangement` API to switch between tasks (eventually it will listen to a gzstring topic). This function does the following:

* Iterate through all the models listed in the `model_name` tags.
    * If a given model has a `pose` tag defined under the specified task, then reset the pose of that model using the arrangement-specific pose.
    * If the given model doesn't have a `pose` tag specified, then reset the pose of that model to its initial pose.

To illustrate how this might be used, I moved the initial pose of all the objects from the table to 250 meters away (`y=-0.25` -> `y=250`). Then if you set `cricket_ball` as the initial arrangement, it will only put the cricket ball on the table. If you set `wood_blocks` as the initial arrangement, it will put the wood blocks on the table but leave the cricket ball far away.

The nice thing is that you can change the arrangements by modifying the plugin xml tags without recompiling the plugin. ~~It's actually kind of a general plugin. Should we give it a more general name than `ARATPlugin`?~~ It has been renamed to ArrangePlugin.

I also added a `Model::ResetPhysicsStates` API to call `Link::ResetPhysicsStates` for each link in a model. This will reset the velocities to zero and is called whenever we change the pose of an object.
values.title: Add ArrangePlugin to arrange models for tasks

  </arrangement>
  <arrangement name="wood_blocks">
    <pose model="wood_block_10_2_1cm"> 0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>

    <pose model="wood_cube_5cm"      >-0.2 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose model="wood_cube_2_5cm"    >-0.4 -0.25 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
  </arrangement>
</plugin>

First, it accepts a sequence of model_name elements, with the names of models that should be arranged. The plugin stores the initial pose of these models internally.

It also accepts a sequence of arrangement elements that have a name attribute (for arrangement name) and child pose elements. The child pose elements have a model attribute that should match one of the model_name tags, and then pose data. Note that an arrangement doesn't require all poses to be listed (this will be explained below).

There is also an initial_arrangement element that should match one of the task names.

There is a ArrangePlugin::SetArrangement API to switch between tasks (eventually it will listen to a gzstring topic). This function does the following:

  • Iterate through all the models listed in the model_name tags.
    • If a given model has a pose tag defined under the specified task, then reset the pose of that model using the arrangement-specific pose.
    • If the given model doesn't have a pose tag specified, then reset the pose of that model to its initial pose.

To illustrate how this might be used, I moved the initial pose of all the objects from the table to 250 meters away (y=-0.25 -> y=250). values.title: Implement WireBox::GetBox

summary.html:
@jacquelinekay and I were trying to get numerical values for some bounding boxes with the following code in Visual.cc:

diff -r d9c44e425086 gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc
--- a/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc    Mon Sep 22 16:00:00 2014 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc    Mon Sep 22 17:09:31 2014 -0700
@@ -1404,6 +1404,10 @@
     }

     this->dataPtr->boundingBox->SetVisible(true);
+    gzerr << this->GetName()
+          << " "
+          << this->dataPtr->boundingBox->GetBox()
+          << std::endl;
   }
   else if (this->dataPtr->boundingBox)
   {

It turns out that WireBox::GetBox is listed in the header file but not implemented. So I'm implementing it here.

values.title: Update changelog for 4.0.2 version
4.0.2 Changelog

values.description:
The `gz` tool now supports output of model info:

1. `gz model -m <model_name> -i`: Output complete model information

2. `gz model -m <model_name> -p`: Output the pose of the model.

This is to address this [drcsim issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/389).
values.title: Update command line tool output model info

summary.raw:
The `gz` tool now supports output of model info:

1. `gz model -m <model_name> -i`: Output complete model information

2. `gz model -m <model_name> -p`: Output the pose of the model.

This is to address this [drcsim issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/389).

values.description:
* Added option to import a floor plan to draw on top of (issue #422)

* Includes tool to help users scale the image (pixels to real world measures)

* Possible to import a different image for each level of the building

* `View` button to toggle visibility of the `Floorplan` or the `Features`

* Fixed bugs with adding/deleting levels and added `-` button (issue  #361 ?)
values.title: Building editor: Import background image and improve add/delete levels

values.description:
`ODEJoint::SetVelocity` has traditionally used the ODE limit motor to set a desired joint velocity, along with a `max_force` parameter. We are planning to use this feature to implement Coulomb joint friction instead (see #381), so a different approach to `ODEJoint::SetVelocity` is required.

The approach is similar to the `Joint::SetPosition` functions from pull request #1096, pull request #1097, and #1138, by creating `Joint::SetVelocityMaximal`, which is used by ODE and bullet to set the velocity of a child link relative to its parent velocity. This is currently the behavior used in bullet and is being generalized here.

Also, the `Joint::[GS]etMaxForce` functions are deprecated, since they were based on the ODE implementation of `Joint::SetVelocity`. This required some modifications to plugins.

I also modified some tests, mainly by deleting code for special cases, though I relaxed the expectations on joint limits slightly in joint_spawn.cc to allow elastic contacts at joint limits.
values.title: Change behavior of ODEJoint::SetVelocity (#964)

The approach is similar to the `Joint::SetPosition` functions from pull request #1096, pull request #1097, and #1138, by creating `Joint::SetVelocityMaximal`, which is used by ODE and bullet to set the velocity of a child link relative to its parent velocity. This is currently the behavior used in bullet and is being generalized here.

Also, the `Joint::[GS]etMaxForce` functions are deprecated, since they were based on the ODE implementation of `Joint::SetVelocity`. This required some modifications to plugins.

I also modified some tests, mainly by deleting code for special cases, though I relaxed the expectations on joint limits slightly in joint_spawn.cc to allow elastic contacts at joint limits.
summary.html:
ODEJoint::SetVelocity has traditionally used the ODE limit motor to set a desired joint velocity, along with a max_force parameter. We are planning to use this feature to implement Coulomb joint friction instead (see #381), so a different approach to ODEJoint::SetVelocity is required.

The approach is similar to the Joint::SetPosition functions from pull request #1096, pull request #1097, and #1138, by creating Joint::SetVelocityMaximal, which is used by ODE and bullet to set the velocity of a child link relative to its parent velocity. This is currently the behavior used in bullet and is being generalized here.

Also, the Joint::[GS]etMaxForce functions are deprecated, since they were based on the ODE implementation of Joint::SetVelocity. This required some modifications to plugins.

I also modified some tests, mainly by deleting code for special cases, though I relaxed the expectations on joint limits slightly in joint_spawn.cc to allow elastic contacts at joint limits.

values.description:
Requires / extends [Pull Request #1214](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1214/building-editor-import-background-image)

Some fine tuning is still needed, not sure if it's priority right now.

# Before #

1. `WallItem` extends `PolylineItem` and requires `LineSegmentItem`

2. `WallItem` (and corresponding SDF model) is composed of several segments

3. Segments on the same polyline linked together at draw time, but can't be linked to segments on other polylines

4. Deleting a segment deletes the whole polyline

5. Selected segment is highlighted on 2D view

6. `MeasureItem` extends `PolylineItem` (only used at `ImportImageView`)

7. Inspector for individual segments, but with whole polyline name, which can be confusing

8. At draw time, segments snap to multiples of 90 (can't be turned off), and when being edited, to multiples of 15 (can be turned off by holding the `Shift` key)


# After #

1. `WallSegmentItem` extends `SegmentItem` - most functionality on both adapted from `WallItem`, `LineSegmentItem` and `PolylineItem`

2. Each `WallSegmentItem` is a single segment

3. Segments can be linked to any other segment at draw time, many segments can be linked on the same point.

* After the segment has been drawn, it can't be snapped to other segments or unsnapped, but this can be implemented

* If a segment is edited at the inspector and appears to lose a link, the link has not been lost and moving the neighbour will move it

4. Deleting a `WallSegmentItem` deletes only that segment and linked segments remain untouched

5. Selected segment is highlighted on 2D view and 3D view

6. `MeasureItem` extends `SegmentItem` and is shown for selected / being drawn wall segments

7. Inspector for each segment as each segment is a model

8. At draw time, segments snap to multiples of 45 or to other segments. When being edited, only to multiples of 45. (All snapping can be turned off by holding the `Shift` key)


### Nice features to add ###

* Group-select (holding `Ctrl` key, box selection on 2D view...)

* Option to unlink currently linked segments (on the inspector? using a hotkey?)

* Measure display for doors and windows

* Translating a segment snaps to its current horizontal / vertical coordinates

values.description:
This was initially submitted as pull request #1206 to resolve issue #381. It was declined so that the `ODEJoint::SetVelocity` implementation could be modified (pull request #1218). Here's the description from pull request #1206:

This pull request uses the `<axis><dynamics><friction>` tag to implement Coulomb joint friction (see Fig 1 in
[this paper](http://robotics.tch.harvard.edu/publications/pdfs/armstrong1994survey.pdf), thanks to @traversaro for the suggestion). It is currently implemented for ODE revolute, prismatic, and universal joints using the velocity and force parameters in the ODE joint motor (see #381 for further discussion).

I've added a section to the `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` test to verify the SetParam("friction", ...) API, and I've also added a demo world: `worlds/joint_friction_demo.world` (note that it is generated from an embedded ruby template with suffix `.rworld`). In this world, there are several joints with different friction values that should behave differently. The universal joints are set to mimic the behavior of the revolute joints.

I should be able to get bullet to work in a similar manner. I will address this in a future pull request.

Assorted comments:

* I moved the sdf parameter loading from ODEJoint::Load to the parent class.
* I had to modify Joint::Reset to allow joint friction values to persist after a world reset (try resetting the demo world to verify that it works).

jenkins

* [no unexpected test failures in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/227/)

* [newer build as of 627cfcc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/238/)

* [final jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/271/): no unexpected failures

values.description:
I updated ArrangePlugin.cc to listen on a topic, specified by the <topic_name> tag in SDF. If the specified topic publishes a GzString message that matches one of the arrangement names specified in SDF, the plugin sets the world to the corresponding arrangement.

There is a very simple example in examples/stand_alone/arrange which shows the functionality of this pull request by cycling through all of the possible arrangements in the world file arrange_test.world. You can build and run it as follows:

```
#!bash
cd <gazebo_root>/examples/stand_alone/arrange
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
gazebo ../arrange_test.world
./arrange_plugin_test
```

This pull request is required to complete the Haptix tasks I'm working this week.

values.description:
Noticed a problem with collada textures while reviewing gazebo_model pull request #[89](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/89/new-door-for-task-5/diff#chg-drc_practice_hinged_door/meshes/door.dae). The original default behavior is to disable lighting and not to receive shadows. This doesn't seem like the common use case so I reversed the behavior. Lighting is enabled by default and the mesh will receive shadows.

![hinged_door_dae.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1547669162-hinged_door_dae.png)

The left image shows the new rendering of the `hinged_door`, compared to the original behavior on the right

values.description:
As documented in #1299, there can be rogue `gzserver` processes left over from failures of the `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test. It happens only occasionally, but when it does happen, it causes all other tests to fail and ties up the build machine until we manually log in to the machine to kill the process.

This pull request modifies the `tools/check_test_ran.py` script to check for leftover `gzserver` processes from the clone test and kill them. It only runs directly after the `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test.

To test this, apply the following patch to cause a test failure:
~~~
diff -r 7cf2bfe6c08a test/integration/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/test/integration/CMakeLists.txt   Fri Oct 10 11:41:12 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/integration/CMakeLists.txt   Tue Oct 14 15:23:37 2014 -0700
@@ -92,6 +92,8 @@
   set_tests_properties(${TEST_TYPE}_factory PROPERTIES TIMEOUT 500)
   set_tests_properties(${TEST_TYPE}_physics PROPERTIES TIMEOUT 500)

+  set_tests_properties(${TEST_TYPE}_world_clone PROPERTIES TIMEOUT 10)
+
   # Add plugin dependency
   add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_joint_test SpringTestPlugin)
 endif()
diff -r 7cf2bfe6c08a test/integration/world_clone.cc
--- a/test/integration/world_clone.cc   Fri Oct 10 11:41:12 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/integration/world_clone.cc   Tue Oct 14 15:23:37 2014 -0700
@@ -195,7 +195,7 @@
   // Check that the cloned world contains the camera topics.
   output = custom_exec_str("gz topic -l");
   EXPECT_NE(output.find("/gazebo/default/camera/"), std::string::npos);
-
+FAIL();
   // Kill the cloned server. In the case of no presence of gzserver ps will
   // return the own ps process so it probably will do nothing. No effect.
   // This should work on Linux and Mac
~~~
and then run the following command:
~~~
$ make test ARGS="-VV -R INTEGRATION_world_clone"
...
$ ps ax | grep 'gzserver.*clone'
~~~
Apply the patch to default to see the failure, apply it to this branch to see the fix.

I was going to wait for a time when there were fewer open pull requests, but I just had to [fix another build machine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/1174/), so I decided it would be helpful sooner than later.

values.title: Added text field to common::KeyEvent

summary.html:
This is a fix for issue 1303. When using common::KeyEvent and gui::KeyEventHandler, there was no built-in way to detect when shift was being pressed to produce an uppercase letter. This pull request adds a "text" field to KeyEvent which stores the Unicode character produced by a key press event. It is found by simply storing the text field of the QKeyEvent which generates the Gazebo Key Event (see QT Documentation).

To test this pull request, add the following line to the constructor of a GUI plugin:

  gui::KeyEventHandler::Instance()->AddPressFilter("gui_example",
    boost::bind(&GUIExampleWidget::OnKeyPress, this, _1));

Write the OnKeyPress function to show you the fields of the KeyEvent:

bool GUIExampleWidget::OnKeyPress(common::KeyEvent _event){
  std::cout << "event.key: " << _event.key << std::endl;
  std::cout << "event.text: " << _event.text << std::endl;
}

event.key will show you the decimal value of the corresponding ascii value while text will give you the unicode string. However, the event.key field will be the same for an uppercase and lowercase letter. For example, 'a' and 'SHIFT-a' will both give a key field of 65, but the text field will read 'a' for the first case and 'A' for the second case.

I rewrote rendering::FPSViewController to pan the camera based on WASD input. The viewpoint rotates when the user holds left click and moves the mouse around.

To use it, insert the following line into your favorite plugin (preferably the constructor of a GUI Plugin):

```
#!c++

  gui::get_active_camera()->SetViewController(
                          rendering::FPSViewController::GetTypeString());
```

Further work on this front: configurable key bindings, configurable camera speed, and an option to set the viewpoint in the GUI. ~~In the meantime, I hope to incorporate this into HAPTIX.~~ no longer needed for Haptix, so not a priority for 10/27/14 sprint

values.description:
This is one of multiple pull requests from my accuracy testing branch.

Since loading physics state is still not working (issue #312), we cannot set initial velocities for links in a world file. This pull request introduces a simple ModelPlugin for setting the initial angular and linear velocity of a model. It takes `<linear>` and `<angular>` tags as sdf parameters and sets the model velocity accordingly (note that model velocity actually means the velocity of the canonical link of the model).
~~~
<plugin name="large_wz" filename="libInitialVelocityPlugin.so">
  <linear>-1 -1 5</linear>
  <angular>0.1 5.0 0.1</angular>
</plugin>
~~~
This is not a general solution, since it doesn't set velocity for multiple links. For the general solution, we should fix loading physics state (#312). I think it is worthwhile, though, because I discovered that plugins could not set the initial velocity during the `Reset` function due to the order of function calls in `Model::Reset`. This fixes the order and provides a simple plugin that will work for single link models.
values.title: InitialVelocityPlugin: set initial state of links

This is one of multiple pull requests from my accuracy testing branch.

Since loading physics state is still not working (issue #312), we cannot set initial velocities for links in a world file. This pull request introduces a simple ModelPlugin for setting the initial angular and linear velocity of a model. It takes <linear> and <angular> tags as sdf parameters and sets the model velocity accordingly (note that model velocity actually means the velocity of the canonical link of the model).

<plugin name="large_wz" filename="libInitialVelocityPlugin.so">

  <angular>0.1 5.0 0.1</angular>
</plugin>

This is not a general solution, since it doesn't set velocity for multiple links. For the general solution, we should fix loading physics state (#312). values.description:
Another accuracy testing pull request.

As discussed in the [ROSCon presentation](http://roscon.ros.org/2014/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/roscon2014_scpeters.pdf), there is a significant difference in numerical stability between the implicit and explicit formulation of sping-damper forces. Our fork of ODE supports both implicit and explicit springs with an SDF parameter, and this pull request provides an API to set that flag. I enabled the `ODEJoint_TEST` and added a section for this function.
values.title: Add function to set whether ODEJoint is using implicit or explicit springs

values.description:
The current behavior of KeyEvents intercepted by GLWidget and handled by KeyEventHandler is to ignore autorepeats, which are repeated key events that occur continuously while the user holds down a button. This pull requests adds two booleans to KeyEventHandler, pressAutoRepeat and releaseAutoRepeat, which are false by default. When GLWidget receives a new key press or key release, it ignores the event if it is an auto repeat and the corresponding autoRepeat bool is false, otherwise it treats the event like a normal key event. 

Because KeyEventHandler is a singleton class, this functionality could cause issues if multiple processes want to use key events with and without autorepeats. However, the current use case for autorepeats (Haptix keyboard teleop) does not require non-autorepeat events.
values.title: Added toggle boolean in KeyEventHandler for enabling auto repeats

values.description:
Hopefully, a simpler, more organized version of pull request #1220 (removed wall measure and highlighting to make the PR smaller).

The basic idea is to substitute the trio `WallItem` + `PolylineItem` + `LineSegmentItem` with `WallSegmentItem` + `SegmentItem`. This requires a new logic for walls to stick together, but facilitates things like selecting and deleting individual segments, connecting to other walls, coloring individual walls and so on.

I made [a spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/a/osrfoundation.org/spreadsheets/d/11Lg9uevyjB6yVnO1Lv_LVjO3ji8ut_ybDEPoW5SSgSo/edit?usp=sharing) summarizing which members went from which class to which class, if it helps anyone reviewing this.

This PR solves issue #389, both issues described on #415 and partially #369 and #393.

I separated out expose MainWindow functionality from Ian and Hugo's branch expose_mainwindow into this branch.

This pull request adds a function GuiIface::get_main_window() that exposes the main graphical window to plugin developers. It also adds a method to GuiEvents, ConnectMainWindowReady, and a signal, mainWindowReady, which is called when the MainWindow is finished initializing. Setting up a subscriber to this signal via ConnectMainWindowReady is the preferred access method to MainWindow.

The example GUI plugin, MainWindowExampleWidget, shows this functionality by calling MainWindow::Pause() as soon as the MainWindow has initialized and printing out a notification to the user.
values.title: Added get_main_window accessor to GuiIface

values.description:
This branch modifies KeyEventHandler and GLWidget so that hotkeys can be suppressed by custom KeyEvents set up by developers.

KeyEventHandler::Handle, HandlePress and HandleRelease now return bool instead of void. When implementing a PressFilter, the developer should return true if the KeyEvent was "handled" and no further events using this key should be called. In GLWidget, KeyEvents trigged in ModelManipulator and UserCamera are suppressed if the return value of KeyEventHandler is true.

Ian suggested this when I discussed it with him earlier today, which is why I'm adding him as a reviewer.
values.title: Modified precedence of key events in GLWidget
